results.title: Taps and toilets
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Waterworks”.
Episode 4, ‘Taps and toilets’, deals with how human usage plays a role in the water cycle. Areas of human usage (both industrial and domestic) are discussed from the source point to the processes used for the purification of waste-water. Increased demand for water has highlighted long-standing problems with water supply including pollution. Forms of pollution discussed are tree clearing, salination and rainwater (carrying pesticides etc to our bays). Also discussed are unconfined aquifers (which explains our Billabongs), and confined aquifers like the Artesian Basin. Narrated by writer and producer Dick Beilby, this program creates relationships between our use of water and broader climatic environment beyond the taps and toilets - “the part of the water cycle that mostly connect with our lives”.

results.title: Urban Aboriginal artists
results.creator_credit: Christoph Willing, David Roberts, Peter Lipscombe and University of Sydney Television Service
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Talking about Aboriginal art”.
While the three artists in this video cannot speak for all city-based Aboriginal artists, they raise issues central to the art-making of urban Aboriginals and the problems and controversies surrounding such art. They discuss issues of identity, their views on differences between black and white Australians and social issues of concern to their communities. Michael Riley has a growing reputation as a photographer and film maker, portraying the myths and misconceptions of Aboriginality. Trevor Nickolls has developed a strong iconography in his paintings which attempt to reconcile his black and white heritage. Jeffrey Samuels portrays his cultural heritage through his paintings using contemporary techniques, reflecting on stereotypes, tradition and nature.

results.title: Freestyle nightclub
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dance Magic”.
Enjoy learning steps in the Nightclub Disco format. The figures may be danced to contemporary or Top 40 music in a variety of settings such as nightclubs, discos and parties.

results.title: Tasmania: its history its heritage
results.creator_credit: Peter Richman and Peter Richman Productions
results.brief_description: This video uses the architecture of yesteryear to analyse what it says about the social, cultural and economic history of Tasmania; Australia’s second oldest colony. There is a variety of architecture and classic buildings examined, from grand homes, public buildings, humble cottages and split paling cabins. Produced in consultation with the National Trust, Tasmania, this video will be enjoyed by anyone interested in historic buildings or the history of Tasmania.

results.title: Aboriginal art: conserving, exhibiting, interpreting
results.creator_credit: Christoph Willing, David Roberts, Peter Lipscombe and University of Sydney Television Service
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Talking about Aboriginal art”.
In recent decades Aboriginal art has increasingly been destined for art museums and major private collections. It has not been totally subsumed into the Western art dealer and museum system, but has made curators and art historians ask some profound questions about their practices and policies of collecting and exhibiting art. One concern is the involvement of non- Aboriginal curators and art advisers, with many believing they occupy positions which would be more appropriately held by Aboriginal people. Curators Djon Mundine, Wally Caruana and Peter Sutton discuss gallery collecting policies, major exhibitions and key issues in the criticism of contemporary Aboriginal art.

results.title: Tradition and change: art from the desert
results.creator_credit: Christoph Willing, David Roberts, Peter Lipscombe and University of Sydney Television Service
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Talking about Aboriginal art”.
In the past two decades Aboriginal art has flourished and diversified to a phenomenal extent. A many-faceted art movement has developed, with artists from communities all around Australia contributing fresh visions. Critics and the general public are excited by its inventiveness and aesthetic appeal. Its difference from traditional Aboriginal art has caused much controversy. Hetti Perkins introduces contemporary Aboriginal art, its themes and the issues. Geoff Bardon gives a personal account of the beginnings of the Papunya painting movement when he encouraged senior men to paint their Dreaming Stories in acrylics. Michael Nelson Jakamarra, recognized internationally as one of the outstanding artists from the Papuya central desert community, talks about his country and his art.
results.title_for_label: Tradition and change: art from the desert
results.creator_credit_for_label: Christoph Willing, David Roberts, Peter Lipscombe and University of Sydney Television Service

results.title: Amazing H2o
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Waterworks”.
‘Episode 2: amazing H2O’ starts with the story of Henry Cavendish (Mark Allen), a rich scientist in the 17th century who made it his mission in life to discover the properties of water. His persistence gave us the H2O chemical name. With 70% of the earth covered in water, it is surprising to learn that scientists know more about the qualities of ice than water itself. Exploring both the realm of the known and unknown, this episode covers the following topics; surface tension, anti-gravitational behaviour, solutions, emulsions, ice, gas, evaporation, crystals. Presented by series producer Dick Beilby.

results.title: Tarzan: the collector's classic
results.creator_credit: Edward Kull, Wilbur McGaugh, Ashton Dearholt, Ben S. Cohen, George W. Stout and Ashton Dearholt Expedition Pictures
results.brief_description: This Tarzan collectors edition contains the full length feature “Tarzan and the Green Goddess” starring Olympic champion Herman Brix. Filmed on location in Guatemala, it details the adventures of Tarzan as he assists the expedition of Major Martling and Ula Vale and their quest to take the Green Goddess, a native totem believed to contain a secret formula for a super explosive, back to Livingston. After successfully finding the totem it is stolen by Raglan who is intent on using the formula for Hiram Power’s personal plots, thus disturbing the delicate balance of the jungle. With only Tarzan’s unique knowledge to rectify the chaos that has been unleashed, so follows the journey on the trail of Raglan. Tarzan and the expedition members must also combat a party of natives sent by the High Priest to avenge the tribe and retrieve the Goddess. This Tarzan collectors edition also contains bonus footage, extracts and out-takes from the films of three other well known Tarzan players, including the first actor to play Edgar Rice Burrough’s adventurous character, Elmo Lincoln.
